## 1. Data collection and cleaning {#data-collection-and-cleaning-1}

Two datasets were collected for this analysis: the National Crime Information Center Missing Person and Unidentified Person Statistics (2007-2022) and the National Missing and Unidentified Persons System (current).

```{r}
# install.packages(c("tidyverse", "janitor", "pdftools", "lubridate", "rvest", "remotes"))
# remotes::install_github("ropensci/tabulizer")

library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)
library(pdftools)
library(lubridate)
library(tabulizer)
library(rvest)
```

### A. National Crime Information Center Missing Person and Unidentified Person Statistics (2007-2022)

The FBI releases yearly reports on missing persons in the U.S. If a missing persons case is reported missing to local law enforcement, they are required to report it to the FBI within two hours of the receiving these reports.

There reports are typically release in early February. The most recent report was released on February 2, 2023 and covered 2022 missing persons cases.

The official name of these reports is the National Crime Information Center Missing Person and Unidentified Person Statistics. The reports contain information relating unidentified persons as well, but for the purpose of my reporting and preview of my article, I will only be focusing on the missing persons data.

There two units of data: entry and purged. Purged includes the number of records that are "cancelled, cleared and located."

"Purged" is much more limited than "entry" in level of aggregation. Though levels of aggregation vary year for both "purged" and "entry" data.

For 2015-22, each year's data was available as PDFs on the FBI website. For 2007-14, each year's data is available as a html page.

Because of the different formats they required different tools.

For the more recent years, the R package tabulizer was used to scrape PDF tables, which requires a Java environment because it connects to Tabula, a java program.

```{r}
url <- c("https://www.fbi.gov/file-repository/", "year here", "-ncic-missing-person-and-unidentified-person-statistics.pdf")

years <- seq(2015, 2022)

for (year in years){
  
  pdf_path <- paste0(url[1], year, url[3])
  
  tables <- extract_tables(pdf_path, output = "data.frame")
  
  # assigns variables to each year
  assign(paste0("missing_persons_stats_", year), tables)
}
```

For the earlier years, rvest was used to scrape the HTML tables.

```{r}
url <- "https://archives.fbi.gov/archives/about-us/cjis/ncic/ncic-missing-person-and-unidentified-person-statistics-for-"

years <- seq(2007, 2014) 

for (year in years) {
  
  page_path <- paste0(url, year)
  
  tables <- 
    page_path %>% 
    read_html() %>% 
    html_table()
  
  # assigns variables to each years
  assign(paste0("missing_persons_stats_", year), tables)
}
```

Every year was formatted slightly differently, so the cleaning prompt had to slightly edited for each year.

Like mentioned earlier the levels of aggregation varied, more specifically, the most recent three years had a great level of depth. So, I chooses to gather more detailed data and then aggregate the data to match the other years. This leaves the older years with NAs for that more detailed data.

```{r echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
  female_minor = rowSums(across(matches("female_[A-Za-z]+_minor"))),
  male_minor = rowSums(across(matches("male_[A-Za-z]+_minor"))),
  female_adult = rowSums(across(matches("female_[A-Za-z]+_adult"))),
  male_adult = rowSums(across(matches("male_[A-Za-z]+_adult"))),
```

After starting my analysis, I re-scraped the three most recent years because it had the most intersectional data. This includes categories provided by the FBI:

Disability: a person of any age who is missing and under proven physical/mental disability or is senile, thereby subjecting him/ herself or others to personal and immediate danger.

Endangered: a person of any age who is missing under circumstances indicating that his/her physical safety may be in danger.

Involuntary: a person of any age who is missing under circumstances indicating that the disappearance may not have been voluntary, i.e., abduction or kidnapping.

Juvenile: a person who is missing and not declared emancipated as defined by the laws of his/her state of residence and does not meet any of the entry criteria set forth in the Disability, Endangered, Involuntary, or Catastrophe Victim categories.

Catastrophe Victim: a person of any age who is missing after a catastrophe.

Other: a person not meeting the criteria for entry in any other category who is missing and 1) for whom there is a reasonable concern for his/her safety or 2) a person who is under age 21 and declared emancipated by the laws of his/her state of residence. In accordance with 34 U.S.C. § 41307(a), agencies are required to enter records into the NCIC Missing Person File for missing individuals under the age of 21

```{r echo=FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
url <- c("https://www.fbi.gov/file-repository/", "year here", "-ncic-missing-person-and-unidentified-person-statistics.pdf")
years <- seq(2020, 2022)

for (year in years){
  pdf_path <- paste0(url[1], year, url[3])
  tables <- extract_tables(pdf_path, output = "data.frame", method = "stream")
  assign(paste0("missing_persons_stats_", year), tables)
}
```

Rather than re-scraping the 2007-19, I chose to transform the data to be able to join with the more detailed data. I chose not to include cases where sex, age or race was not entered. Though this may be representative of underrepresented identity (however, I think this is unlikely), due to lower number, they are not statistically significant.

```{r}
fbi_ncic <-
  missing_persons_entry_by_sex_race_age %>%
  pivot_longer(-c(1),names_to = "name", values_to = "value") %>%
  mutate(name = str_replace_all(name, "unknown_", "unknown")) %>% 
  separate(col=name, into=c("sex", "race", "age"), sep="_") %>%
  mutate(age = case_when(
    race == "minor" ~ "minor",
    race == "adult" ~ "adult",
    race == "unknownage" ~ "unknown",
    TRUE ~ age
  ),
  race = case_when(
    sex == "indian" ~ "indian",
    sex == "black" ~ "black",
    sex == "asian" ~ "asian",
    sex == "white" ~ "white",
    sex == "unknownrace" ~ "unknown",
    TRUE ~ race
  ),
  sex = case_when(
    sex == "female" ~ "female",
    sex == "male" ~ "male",
    sex == "unknownsex" ~ "unknown",
    TRUE ~ NA_character_
  ),
  race = case_when(
    race == "black" ~ "black",
    race == "white" ~ "white",
    race == "asian" ~ "asian",
    race == "indian" ~ "indian",
    race == "unknownrace" ~ "unknown",
    TRUE ~ NA_character_
  )) %>% 
  filter(!is.na(value)) %>% 
  filter(year != "2022", year != "2021", year != "2020") %>%
  mutate(cat=NA) %>% 
  rbind(intersectional_missing_persons) %>% 
  arrange(desc(year)) %>% 
  select(year, race, sex, age, cat, value)

fbi_ncic
```

### B. National Missing and Unidentified Persons System (current)

The National Missing and Unidentified Persons System is public database of missing persons and unlike the FBI reports, has no aggregation. However, cases are only entered into this database on a voluntary basis and thus is not a representative sample of missing persons in the U.S.

Over email, spokesperson warned me, "Participation in NamUs is voluntary therefore trends in missing person data may not correlate with actual missing persons cases reported to law enforcement."

The cases are vetted with local law enforcement for accuracy before entry.

This database also only includes active missing cases. I did request for the purged records in hopes of learning about the potential disparities in length individual are missing, which have been reported in the missing persons literature. My request was successful. However, the records did not provide dates, without this important context, the request proved useless. These records are available here [link needed].

Due to the nature of the records, I felt that it was important to present the most recent data.

So, I used Github actions and a Python script to update these records daily. Most information is available on my Github repository.

I used Playwright to accomplish this.

Playwright opens a browser, logs into the NamUs database, which is required for download data and downloads the entire database.

```{python python.reticulate = FALSE}
from playwright.sync_api import Playwright, sync_playwright
import os
from decouple import config

def scrape():
    try:
        namus_password = os.environ['NAMUS_PASSWORD']
    except:
        namus_password = config('NAMUS_PASSWORD')
    
    destination_folder_path = "./data/"
    
    # users are only allowed to download 10,000 records at a time
    yearss = [{"start": "1875", "end": "2014"}, {"start": "2015", "end": "2020"},{"start": '2021', "end": "2023"}]
    
    with sync_playwright() as p:

        browser = p.chromium.launch(headless=True)
        context = browser.new_context()
        page = context.new_page()
        page.goto("https://www.namus.gov/dashboard")

        page.click("#NavLogin")
        page.fill("#loginUsername", "coleschnell@gmail.com")
        page.fill("#loginPassword", namus_password)
        page.click("#LoginSubmit")

        page.wait_for_selector(".user-avatar")

        page.click(".search-link")

        for years in yearss:
          
            # Select the years
            page.locator("xpath=/html/body/div[1]/div[4]/form/div[1]/section[2]/div/div[2]/div/div/section/div/div/article[1]/div/div[5]/div/div[3]/div/date-range-input/div/div[2]/div[1]/div[1]/date-input/div/years-input/select").select_option(years["start"])
            page.locator("xpath=/html/body/div[1]/div[4]/form/div[1]/section[2]/div/div[2]/div/div/section/div/div/article[1]/div/div[5]/div/div[3]/div/date-range-input/div/div[2]/div[1]/div[2]/date-input/div/years-input/select").select_option(years["end"])
            
            page.click("input.button-save")

            page.wait_for_selector("a.view-link")
            page.screenshot(path="search_results.png")
            page.locator("a.view-link").click()
            
            with page.expect_download() as download_info:
                download = download_info.value
            file_name = "results" + years["start"] + "_" + years["end"]+ ".csv"
            download.save_as(os.path.join(destination_folder_path, file_name))

            page.go_back()

        browser.close()
```

I used another python script to combine and compare the data with the previous days' scrapes, logging any purged or added records.

```{python  python.reticulate = FALSE}
import pandas as pd
import os
from datetime import datetime
from skimpy import clean_columns
import pickle
import pytz

def combine():
  
    destination_folder_path = "./data/"
    
    yearss = [{"start": "1875", "end": "2014"}, {"start": "2015", "end": "2020"},{"start": '2021', "end": "2023"}]
    
    today = datetime.now((pytz.timezone('US/Central'))).strftime('%Y-%m-%d')

    try:
        with open(os.path.join(destination_folder_path, "scrape_record.pkl"), 'rb') as f:
            scrape_record = pickle.load(f)
    except:
        scrape_record = {}

    scrape_record[str(today)] = {}
    new = pd.DataFrame()

    try:
        old = pd.read_csv(os.path.join(destination_folder_path, "combined.csv"))
    except:
        old = pd.DataFrame()
    try:
        purged = pd.read_csv(os.path.join(destination_folder_path, "purged.csv"))
    except:
        purged = pd.DataFrame()

    for years in yearss:
        file_name = "results" + years["start"] + "_" + years["end"]+ ".csv"
        df = pd.read_csv(os.path.join(destination_folder_path, file_name))
        new = pd.concat([new,df], ignore_index=True)

    new = clean_columns(new)
    combined = pd.concat([old,new], ignore_index=True)
    combined.drop_duplicates(inplace=True)

    # Perform anit-join
    try:
        outer = new.merge(old, how='outer', indicator=True)
        new_entry = outer[(outer._merge=='left_only')].drop('_merge', axis=1)
        new_entry = clean_columns(new_entry)
        scrape_record[today]["new_entries"] = len(new_purged)
    except:
        print("No records entered")
        scrape_record[today]["new_entries"] = 0
    
    try:
        outer = old.merge(new, how='outer', indicator=True)
        new_purged = outer[(outer._merge=='left_only')].drop('_merge', axis=1)
        new_purged["purge_date"] = today
        new_purged = clean_columns(new_purged)
        scrape_record[today]["purged"] = len(new_purged)
        purged = pd.concat([purged,new_purged], ignore_index=True)
    except:
        print("No records purged")
        scrape_record[today]["purged"] = 0
    
    scrape_record[today]["total_records"] = len(combined)
    scrape_record[today]["total_purged"] = len(purged)

    with open(os.path.join(destination_folder_path, "scrape_record.pkl"), 'wb') as f:
        pickle.dump(scrape_record, f)

    combined.to_csv(os.path.join(destination_folder_path, "combined.csv"), index=False)
    purged.to_csv(os.path.join(destination_folder_path, "purged.csv"), index=False)
```

```{r}
      summarise(relative_risk_race_age=(sum(cases)/sum(pop))/mean(per_one)) %>% 
      ungroup(),
    by=c("race", "age", "year")
  )  %>%

  mutate(
    relative_risk_race_isolated = relative_risk_race - 1,
    relative_risk_sex_isolated = relative_risk_sex - 1,

    relative_risk_race_age_isolated = relative_risk_race_age - relative_risk_race_isolated - relative_risk_age_isolated - 1,
    relative_risk_race_sex_isolated = relative_risk_race_sex - relative_risk_race_isolated - relative_risk_sex_isolated - 1,

) %>%
```
